FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1884.

N.W. COUNCIL ELECTION.

It may strike many that the discussion of matters pertaining to the election of a representative of this electoral district in the North West Council for the next two years is rather premature, but we were they aware of the amount of interest which has been taken by some for any part taken with regard to the election of the coming member, they would no longer hold that opinion. In fact many, if not most of us, feel equally surprised and delighted to learn that we are not to be put to the trouble of exercising our minds with the selection of a candidate at all. Certain gentlemen actuated by the slightest suspicion of the matter as well as all others concerning what is likely to prove most beneficial to the inhabitants of the Territories at large, have been favorably impressed with the proposal to have very kindly decided that one of themselves must be the coming man, as the providential and bestowed upon them serves merely to afford them deeper insight into what is for the best. If the proposal does not extend to the immediate measures required to give effect to their inspired views, they have to confound, in case of our community as a whole, the provisions which are made for all of these arrangements, have to recur to the vulgar and disgustingly earthly state old lodges of putting up two names to split the vote, one of which will hardly be elected, at least at this juncture which will no doubt be duly revealed to them as the right one, resign in favor of the other. Were it absolutely certain that the inspiration referred to was genuine, and that damned for we would allow the electors to rejoice and to cooperate instead of kicking against the pricks. We would say then that however unsatisfactory it might be, men manifest entirely in experience, with the most imperfect if any liberal education, to the casual eye seemingly actuated by selfish motives only, and representing principles by insensible self-sufficiency, we must remember that when viewed by the light of faith, what appears most distasteful may in reality be unconditionally for our good. It is well not to regard the question as a question, but to take time to consider a decision and have no doubt that in due time we will feel irresistibly drawn in the right direction.

Prince Albert - N.W.T.
WINTER AMUSEMENTS.

There can be no reason why the winter evening public entertainments which have afforded so much harm-
ful amusement to our citizens with more or less regularity during the past six winters here, should not be made most successful this year, and we attribute so much import-
ance to the fact that we feel our read-
ers will think the space devoted to a few remarks about them by far too means wasted. The reason for do-
ing so just now is that so far we have not heard of any active measures to organize anything of the kind, and the season for them has already been
centered upon, while the existence here of so much and varied talent of the necessary sort, renders some organ-
ized effort all that is necessary to provide a regular series of first-class entertainments such as cannot fail not only to contribute to the pleasure, but also to the moral and social benefit of all the people of our town. Six years ago the strong con-
victions of our citizens could hardly be expected from the introduction of some social recreation of an improv-
ing yet not too heavy kind, led to the institution of what, for want of a better name, were designated Penny Reading Rooms. Many of these rooms in the way at that stage of the settle-
ment's development drew forth the most melancholy prognostications with regard to the result, which how-
ever were found to be altogether groundless as the expectations of the promoters of the scheme were more than realized, and the per-
formances of the original society were pronounced, more especially during the latter part of the season, by competent judges to be such as would have deserved credit under far more favorable circum-
stances. The following year the so-
ciety met a natural death, which un-
fortunately silenced its voice, but was chiefly to the fact that the for that time considerable influx of strangers had not had time to coalesce with the people already settled here. The new entertainments provided until last winter, although the performances were only occasional, and the result of fitful efforts. Last winter the entertainments, which were all formed on the original model, were furnished with tolerable regularity in connection with the Voice Men's Literary Society, while others with a strictly musical programme were intro-
duced in aid of the newly formed and much appreciated brass band which is now doing a good work feature of our winter life. We note too that as a result of the great suc-
cess attending the first attempt at private theatricals in our settlement, offers were made for the entertainment of his-
tories to a generous width who hap-
pily had been afforded pleasant hours to his friends, the performance of amateur theatricals became a regu-
lar institution. In urging that im-
mediate action be taken with the end referred to, we are assisted by the certain knowledge that as young folks will by an inevitable law of na-
ture find amusement of some sort, the only effect of failing to supply such as is at once wholesome and im-
proving, will be the taking refuge in something, to put it mildly, of a less innocent nature. We are pre-

SASKATCHEWAN DIOCESE.

His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan returned to Prince Albert on Friday last from his missionary tour in the new part of the Diocese. His journey extended as far as Lagun in the Rocky Mountains where seven mission Indians gathered. At Lagun he said the 15th of October he held an ordination when the Rev. W. W. Thomas was ordained to the Diaconate. Mr. Thomas is now studying at St. Michael's Missionary School's Diligent College, where he was admitted to the Priestly Orders. Mr. Thomas was ordained by the Bishop of Saskatchewan before he left England. The Rev. P. K. Smith, M.A., of the University of Toronto, was present. Mr. Gagnon acted as temporary Chaplain to the Bishop and presented the candidate. The Rev. J. T. Travis of Fort Macleod assisted in the ceremony. The Bishop preached both morning and evening to large congregations and took pains to explain the doctrine of the church as shown both by pastors and people, in their having in so short a time arrived at the very highest degree of thought which they were assembled. The offerings at the two services combined was more than the church had ever received.

The following day the Bishop visited the mission at the Blackfoot Crossing where he met the children who called "Crowfoot" and shook the whole Blackfoot tribe. The mission school house was filled in the afternoon with the children who came to see "Crowfoot" and the chief sent in rank named "Old Sun" made long speeches in reply to the Bishop. The Bishop told the history of the mission to them to listen to the Missionary, to send their children to school, to be guided by the Bible, to work, to improve themselves by learning to farm and make practical trades. He pointed out to them how kind and generous the government was in taking such pains to teach them how to improve their condition. The replies of the children were very satisfactory, indicating a wish to be pious and a desire feeling of the importance of doing things in the right way. The Rev. W. W. Thomas is in charge of the mission is making rapid progress among the Indians and has been a successful missionary. He had the children in singing hymn songs in Blackfoot.

The Bishop was present at the Provincial Assembly at Regina the first week of October, and returned to Winnipeg to take part in the celebration of the opening of Parliament on the 15th Oct. On the journey homewards he met with a serious accident. He was obliged to leave accompanied him through all the long journey and returned with him in good health.

TELEGRAFIC.

By Special Telegraphic The Times Of April 28, Nov. 7 - In the House of Lords Earl Russell and the Government had no chance to recover in the event of the defeat of the King's and capture of the Queen.

Lord Wolseley has arrived at Douglas. The South Act was carried in both Houses of Parliament, but the South Act and majority of the ballot papers were stolen, probably by the anti-Souths. The bill will not affect the South.

A disastrous fire occurred Saturday between negroes and Democrats at Baton Rouge, Louisiana, and many lives and two hundred ballot boxes were stolen, probably by the anti-Souths. The fire did not affect the South.

The President's contest is still undecided, both parties claiming the victory. The tall returns are not yet to hand.

A heavy gale of wind accompanied by a heavy fall of snow was reported from the Gulf of St. Lawrence. Great damage has been done to property at Quebec. Hundreds of trees have been uprooted.

A shipwreck was made by the sea in the road bed of the Polar colonial at Rio, and trains are unable to transfer.

We regret to hear that Mr. George Hart is suffering from a severe attack of consumption of the lungs.

POLICE NEWS.

Sept. Gagnon is in command at Carleton.

Sergeant Major Dunn with Const. Wm. Metzler, Fleming and Hinch arrived from Carleton on Saturday and returned on Tuesday morning.

Sergeant Gagnon returned on Saturday and left again on Tuesday for Carleton where he is at present to be stationed.

The Bishop visited the new school at Crowfoot yesterday. A strong guard of constables with four large cells has been erected by Captains Cookson and Kierman.

The Rev. Mr. Monkman and Humphrey are being tried this afternoon before Judge Belson.

Mr. T. E. Baker, of this town, was married last evening to Miss Florence A. Murray, daughter of Mr. Murray, who resides in this town. Mr. J. W. Reid. We tender the happy couple our hearty congratulations.
